concept.title: Topic metadata
concept.shortdesc: All topics have the same prolog structure, where you can store information about the topic such as its audience, keywords, and author.

conbody.p: While you can provide a lot of information in a topic's metadata, it can often be more efficient to manage the same information in maps, where you can define metadata for whole groups of topics at a time.

section.title: Prolog categories
section.p:
Prolog metadata falls into the following general categories: Document creation The <author>, <publisher>, and <source> elements help track how a document was created and published.
Document lifecycle The <copyright>, <critdates>, and <permissions> elements help track the lifecycle of a document.
Document subject The <metadata> element organizes information about audience, category, keywords, product information, and other metadata.
Document identity The <resourceid> element lets you create unique ids for different help system requirements.

section.title: Important elements
section.p: You don't need to use every element in the prolog. Much of the information in the prolog, such as copyright dates, may be better left to tools and publication processes to handle. Of the information that does need to be hand-authored, particularly the contents of the metadata element, some information may be better handled in a map. For example, when a topic gets reused in a new context, new synonyms and audience definitions may need to be applied, and a map is the appropriate vehicle.

You should use the contents of the prolog's metadata element as follows: audience Can be used to provide detailed information about a target audience, to supplement the value in the audience attribute of the topic's root element. Be careful to coordinate your definitions with the rest of your team. Audience definitions should come out of a thorough analysis of your product's audiences, and be consistent across your product information set. If your information set has two or three different understandings of administrator skill set and responsibilities, the result will not be useful to actual administrators trying to search or filter your information.
category Can be used to assign the topic to a category, which can classify the topic for retrieval or navigation. For example, the categories could be used to group topics in a generated navigation pane. Topics can belong to multiple categories.
keywords Should be used to provide synonyms for search results, as well as to define index entries for the topic as a whole. Be careful with synonym usage: while it can help users coming from different product backgrounds who are unfamiliar with your product's terminology, it can also confuse users who search on a term and get back a document that doesn't obviously apply.
prodinfo Can be used to provide detailed information about a product that the topic is used in, to supplement the value in the product attribute of the topic's root element. Be careful to coordinate your definitions with the rest of your team. Inconsistent use of product identifiers will make filtering of your information set problematic.
othermeta Can be used to provide other sorts of metadata, for use in customized processing or to produce specific kinds of XHTML metadata elements not available otherwise.
